title: How to Remove Crayon from the Wall

steps.headline: Wet a magic eraser in warm water and wring it out.
steps.description: Turn on the hot water on your sink and run a magic eraser under it. Make sure it gets completely saturated before turning your sink off. Turn off your sink once the magic eraser is wet and squeeze it to wring out the excess water. You can buy a magic eraser in the cleaning section of any big box store. Only use warm or hot water since it will help the crayon wax melt on your wall.

steps.headline: Test the eraser to see if it damages your wall.
steps.description: Pick a small inconspicuous area on your wall to try the magic eraser. Scrub the wall with light pressure to see if it lifts up any paint or leaves any scratches. If the eraser doesn't cause any damage, you can use it on your crayon marks. If the eraser leaves damage, try using a different cleaning method.Tip: Some areas you can test the magic eraser include behind furniture or in a corner close to the floor.

steps.headline: Scrub the crayon with the eraser.
steps.description: Hold the magic eraser over the crayon so some of the heat from the water will melt the wax, and then use circular motions to scrub the wall clean. Keep working across your wall until you remove all of the crayon. If one side of the magic eraser gets too dirty, flip it over so you can use the clean side. If you have wood paneling, make sure to wipe the crayon along the wood grain.

methods.name: Scrubbing with Toothpaste and Baking Soda

steps.headline: Spread a thin layer of toothpaste over the crayon.
steps.description: Use a white toothpaste so you don't leave any other stains on your wall. Hold the tube of toothpaste directly against the wall and squeeze it onto the crayon. Move the tube of toothpaste across all of the crayon marks to coat them evenly. Look for toothpaste labeled for tooth whitening since it usually contains baking soda and can help break down the crayon wax better.

steps.headline: Make a paste out of baking soda and water.
steps.description: Combine 1 tablespoon (17 g) of baking soda and 1 US tbsp (15 ml) of warm water together in a small dish. Use a toothbrush to mix the solution together until it forms a paste-like consistency. For more cleaning power, you can also use white vinegar instead of water. Just be sure to test the mixture on a discrete part of your wall before using it.

steps.headline: Dip a toothbrush into the baking soda and scrub the crayon.
steps.description: Wet the end of a stiff-bristled toothbrush in your baking soda paste so it's completely saturated. Work in small circular movements to work the baking soda and toothpaste into the crayon and lift it from your wall. Rinse the toothbrush occasionally in warm water and apply more paste if you need to. Make sure you use a toothbrush that's only meant for cleaning purposes. Test the baking soda in a discrete area on your wall to see if it affects the color or causes any damage.Tip: If you're cleaning paneling, scrub along the wood grain so you don't leave any marks or scratches.

steps.headline: Wipe the wall clean with a wet cloth.
steps.description: Once all of the crayon is removed, wet a cleaning cloth with warm water and wring it out. Wipe the area you cleaned with the toothpaste and baking soda so it doesn't leave any damage on your walls. If there's any leftover crayon, try scrubbing it with the wet cloth before applying more paste. If you have wallpaper, go over the area with a dry cloth so the paper doesn't start to peel or bubble.

steps.headline: Apply a thin layer of mayonnaise on the crayon and wait 5 minutes.
steps.description: Any store-bought mayonnaise will work for cleaning the crayon. Use a spoon or a butter knife to spread a thin coat of mayo over the crayon marks. Let the mayo sit on the crayon for at least 5 minutes so it has time to set. The oils in mayonnaise will help break down the crayon wax and make it easier to remove. Be careful not to scratch your walls when you apply the mayo.

steps.headline: Scrub the mayo off the wall with a clean cloth.
steps.description: Apply a firm amount of pressure while you clean the mayonnaise off your wall. Rub the mayo in small circles to work it into the crayon and lift the crayon wax from your wall. Apply more mayonnaise if there are still crayon marks after you scrub it.Tip: If the crayon isn't coming off when you scrub it with a cloth, try using something more abrasive, such as a magic eraser.

steps.headline: Wipe the wall clean with a cloth soaked in soapy water.
steps.description: After you've removed as much of the crayon as you can, wet a cleaning cloth in water mixed with liquid dish soap and wring it out. Wipe away any remaining crayon marks and mayonnaise that are left on your wall so it doesn't cause damage or smell later. Dry your wall afterward if you have wallpaper. Otherwise, it could start to peel or absorb the water. Be sure to use a non-abrasive cloth so you don't leave any damage on your walls.

methods.name: Heating the Crayon with a Blow Dryer

steps.headline: Heat up the crayon with the lowest setting on a hair dryer.
steps.description: Plug your hair dryer into the outlet that's closest to your crayon marks. Hold the dryer's nozzle about 6 in (15 cm) from your wall and turn it on. Use the lowest heat setting so you don't cause any damage to your walls. The heat from the hair dryer will help melt the wax and make it easier to wipe away.

steps.headline: Wipe the crayon marks off with baby wipes.
steps.description: As you heat the crayon wax with your hair dryer, use a baby wipe to scrub the marks from your wall. Work in small circular motions or along the wood grain if your wall is made of paneling. Flip the baby wipe over once one side gets too dirty, and use a new baby wipe if you need to. Alternate between heating the crayon with the hair dryer and cleaning it off with the wipes for the most effectiveness. Baby wipes have a gentle cleanser so they shouldn't leave any damage on your walls. Always test your cleaning product in an inconspicuous spot to see how it affects your wall.

steps.headline: Wipe off any residue with a dry cloth.
steps.description: Once most of the crayon is removed, use a dry microfiber cloth to wipe your walls again to remove any residue left by the baby wipes. Focus on any areas where there are small crayon marks to see if they will break off your wall. If not, try heating them again before wiping them clean.

text: Using a Magic Eraser Wet a magic eraser in warm water and wring it out. Turn on the hot water on your sink and run a magic eraser under it. Make sure it gets completely saturated before turning your sink off. Turn off your sink once the magic eraser is wet and squeeze it to wring out the excess water. You can buy a magic eraser in the cleaning section of any big box store. Only use warm or hot water since it will help the crayon wax melt on your wall. Test the eraser to see if it damages your wall. Pick a small inconspicuous area on your wall to try the magic eraser. Scrub the wall with light pressure to see if it lifts up any paint or leaves any scratches. If the eraser doesn't cause any damage, you can use it on your crayon marks. If the eraser leaves damage, try using a different cleaning method.Tip: Some areas you can test the magic eraser include behind furniture or in a corner close to the floor. Scrub the crayon with the eraser. Hold the magic eraser over the crayon so some of the heat from the water will melt the wax, and then use circular motions to scrub the wall clean. Keep working across your wall until you remove all of the crayon. If one side of the magic eraser gets too dirty, flip it over so you can use the clean side. If you have wood paneling, make sure to wipe the crayon along the wood grain. Scrubbing with Toothpaste and Baking Soda Spread a thin layer of toothpaste over the crayon. Use a white toothpaste so you don't leave any other stains on your wall. Hold the tube of toothpaste directly against the wall and squeeze it onto the crayon. Move the tube of toothpaste across all of the crayon marks to coat them evenly. Look for toothpaste labeled for tooth whitening since it usually contains baking soda and can help break down the crayon wax better. Make a paste out of baking soda and water. Combine 1 tablespoon (17 g) of baking soda and 1 US tbsp (15 ml) of warm water together in a small dish. Use a toothbrush to mix the solution together until it forms a paste-like consistency. For more cleaning power, you can also use white vinegar instead of water. Just be sure to test the mixture on a discrete part of your wall before using it. Dip a toothbrush into the baking soda and scrub the crayon. Wet the end of a stiff-bristled toothbrush in your baking soda paste so it's completely saturated. Work in small circular movements to work the baking soda and toothpaste into the crayon and lift it from your wall. Rinse the toothbrush occasionally in warm water and apply more paste if you need to. Make sure you use a toothbrush that's only meant for cleaning purposes. Test the baking soda in a discrete area on your wall to see if it affects the color or causes any damage.Tip: If you're cleaning paneling, scrub along the wood grain so you don't leave any marks or scratches. Wipe the wall clean with a wet cloth. Once all of the crayon is removed, wet a cleaning cloth with warm water and wring it out. Wipe the area you cleaned with the toothpaste and baking soda so it doesn't leave any damage on your walls. If there's any leftover crayon, try scrubbing it with the wet cloth before applying more paste. If you have wallpaper, go over the area with a dry cloth so the paper doesn't start to peel or bubble. Cleaning Crayon with Mayonnaise Apply a thin layer of mayonnaise on the crayon and wait 5 minutes. Any store-bought mayonnaise will work for cleaning the crayon. Use a spoon or a butter knife to spread a thin coat of mayo over the crayon marks. Let the mayo sit on the crayon for at least 5 minutes so it has time to set. The oils in mayonnaise will help break down the crayon wax and make it easier to remove. Be careful not to scratch your walls when you apply the mayo. Scrub the mayo off the wall with a clean cloth. Apply a firm amount of pressure while you clean the mayonnaise off your wall. Rub the mayo in small circles to work it into the crayon and lift the crayon wax from your wall. Apply more mayonnaise if there are still crayon marks after you scrub it.Tip: If the crayon isn't coming off when you scrub it with a cloth, try using something more abrasive, such as a magic eraser. Wipe the wall clean with a cloth soaked in soapy water. After you've removed as much of the crayon as you can, wet a cleaning cloth in water mixed with liquid dish soap and wring it out. Wipe away any remaining crayon marks and mayonnaise that are left on your wall so it doesn't cause damage or smell later. Dry your wall afterward if you have wallpaper. Otherwise, it could start to peel or absorb the water. Be sure to use a non-abrasive cloth so you don't leave any damage on your walls. Heating the Crayon with a Blow Dryer Heat up the crayon with the lowest setting on a hair dryer. Plug your hair dryer into the outlet that's closest to your crayon marks. Hold the dryer's nozzle about 6 in (15 cm) from your wall and turn it on. Use the lowest heat setting so you don't cause any damage to your walls. The heat from the hair dryer will help melt the wax and make it easier to wipe away. Wipe the crayon marks off with baby wipes. As you heat the crayon wax with your hair dryer, use a baby wipe to scrub the marks from your wall. Work in small circular motions or along the wood grain if your wall is made of paneling. Flip the baby wipe over once one side gets too dirty, and use a new baby wipe if you need to. Alternate between heating the crayon with the hair dryer and cleaning it off with the wipes for the most effectiveness. Baby wipes have a gentle cleanser so they shouldn't leave any damage on your walls. Always test your cleaning product in an inconspicuous spot to see how it affects your wall. Wipe off any residue with a dry cloth. Once most of the crayon is removed, use a dry microfiber cloth to wipe your walls again to remove any residue left by the baby wipes. Focus on any areas where there are small crayon marks to see if they will break off your wall. If not, try heating them again before wiping them clean.

Turn on the hot water on your sink and run a magic eraser under it.
Make sure it gets completely saturated before turning your sink off.
Turn off your sink once the magic eraser is wet and squeeze it to wring out the excess water.
You can buy a magic eraser in the cleaning section of any big box store.
Only use warm or hot water since it will help the crayon wax melt on your wall.

Keep working across your wall until you remove all of the crayon.

If you have wood paneling, make sure to wipe the crayon along the wood grain.
Scrubbing with Toothpaste and Baking Soda Spread a thin layer of toothpaste over the crayon.
Use a white toothpaste so you don't leave any other stains on your wall.
Hold the tube of toothpaste directly against the wall and squeeze it onto the crayon.
Move the tube of toothpaste across all of the crayon marks to coat them evenly.
Look for toothpaste labeled for tooth whitening since it usually contains baking soda and can help break down the crayon wax better.
Make a paste out of baking soda and water.
Combine 1 tablespoon (17 g) of baking soda and 1 US tbsp (15 ml) of warm water together in a small dish.
Use a toothbrush to mix the solution together until it forms a paste-like consistency.
For more cleaning power, you can also use white vinegar instead of water.
Just be sure to test the mixture on a discrete part of your wall before using it.
Dip a toothbrush into the baking soda and scrub the crayon.
Wet the end of a stiff-bristled toothbrush in your baking soda paste so it's completely saturated.
Work in small circular movements to work the baking soda and toothpaste into the crayon and lift it from your wall.
Rinse the toothbrush occasionally in warm water and apply more paste if you need to.
Make sure you use a toothbrush that's only meant for cleaning purposes.

Test the baking soda in a discrete area on your wall to see if it affects the color or causes any damage.Tip: If you're cleaning paneling, scrub along the wood grain so you don't leave any marks or scratches.
Wipe the wall clean with a wet cloth.
Once all of the crayon is removed, wet a cleaning cloth with warm water and wring it out.
Wipe the area you cleaned with the toothpaste and baking soda so it doesn't leave any damage on your walls.
If there's any leftover crayon, try scrubbing it with the wet cloth before applying more paste.
If you have wallpaper, go over the area with a dry cloth so the paper doesn't start to peel or bubble.
Cleaning Crayon with Mayonnaise Apply a thin layer of mayonnaise on the crayon and wait 5 minutes.
Any store-bought mayonnaise will work for cleaning the crayon.
Use a spoon or a butter knife to spread a thin coat of mayo over the crayon marks.
Let the mayo sit on the crayon for at least 5 minutes so it has time to set.
The oils in mayonnaise will help break down the crayon wax and make it easier to remove.
Be careful not to scratch your walls when you apply the mayo.
Scrub the mayo off the wall with a clean cloth.
Apply a firm amount of pressure while you clean the mayonnaise off your wall.
Rub the mayo in small circles to work it into the crayon and lift the crayon wax from your wall.
Apply more mayonnaise if there are still crayon marks after you scrub it.Tip: If the crayon isn't coming off when you scrub it with a cloth, try using something more abrasive, such as a magic eraser.
Wipe the wall clean with a cloth soaked in soapy water.
After you've removed as much of the crayon as you can, wet a cleaning cloth in water mixed with liquid dish soap and wring it out.
Wipe away any remaining crayon marks and mayonnaise that are left on your wall so it doesn't cause damage or smell later.
Dry your wall afterward if you have wallpaper.
Otherwise, it could start to peel or absorb the water.
Be sure to use a non-abrasive cloth so you don't leave any damage on your walls.
Heating the Crayon with a Blow Dryer Heat up the crayon with the lowest setting on a hair dryer.
Plug your hair dryer into the outlet that's closest to your crayon marks.
Hold the dryer's nozzle about 6 in (15 cm) from your wall and turn it on.
Use the lowest heat setting so you don't cause any damage to your walls.
The heat from the hair dryer will help melt the wax and make it easier to wipe away.
Wipe the crayon marks off with baby wipes.
As you heat the crayon wax with your hair dryer, use a baby wipe to scrub the marks from your wall.
Work in small circular motions or along the wood grain if your wall is made of paneling.
Flip the baby wipe over once one side gets too dirty, and use a new baby wipe if you need to.
Alternate between heating the crayon with the hair dryer and cleaning it off with the wipes for the most effectiveness.
Baby wipes have a gentle cleanser so they shouldn't leave any damage on your walls.
Always test your cleaning product in an inconspicuous spot to see how it affects your wall.
Wipe off any residue with a dry cloth.
Once most of the crayon is removed, use a dry microfiber cloth to wipe your walls again to remove any residue left by the baby wipes.
Focus on any areas where there are small crayon marks to see if they will break off your wall.
If not, try heating them again before wiping them clean.
